awd_titl_txt: SACNAS Minority Physicists Support Project; NSHP/SACNAS National Conference Sept/Oct 2012-2014 at Southeastern Universities Research Association
awd_abstract_narration: This award supports the partnership between the National Society of Hispanic Physicists (NSHP) and the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS).   The aim of the partnership is to increase the presence of physics, broadly defined, at the SACNAS National Conference.   This annual conference is an opportunity for a talented group of predominantly Hispanic and Native-American students to interact with students and professionals in their disciplines, to present their research results, to learn about cutting-edge research, and to attend a variety of professional development sessions.   This award will support the travel of a total of approximately forty students over three years to the conference.   The award will also support the attendance of four professionals per year; these will be NSHP members who participate in the NSHP sessions and judge the physics and physics-related presentations.   The award is supported by the Division of Physics, the Division of Materials Research, and the Division of Astronomical Sciences.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project supported students in the areas of physics and astronomy, broadly defined, to attend the National Conference of the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics in Science (SACNAS) each year from 2012 - 2014. Partial support for several scientific speakers was also provided by the grant. The physics/astronomy part of this Conference is organized by the National Society of Hispanic Physicists (NSHP). The grant is awarded to the Southeastern Universities Universities Research Association (SURA) under whose sponsorship NSHP is incorporated as a federal not-for-profit 501(C)3 corporation. The goal of the Conference is to increase the participation of Hispanics and Native Americans entering the fields of science and technology with the NSHP partnership focusing on the areas of physics and astronomy broadly defined. The participation rate of Hispanics in Physics and Astronomy, normalized for the population, is significantly lower than for many fields.  NSHP organizes five science sessions, with at least one in astronomy, one in materials/nano-physics, and one in nuclear/particle physics in order to cover the breadth of the physics field. Physics education research and space physics are among the other topics commonly chosen. We also organize several physics/astronomy professional development/leadership sessions, such as practice for taking the Physics Graduate Record Exam or a session on something like transitioning from the postdoc position to a junior faculty. We  broadly advertise the Conference through our newsletter, The Hispanic Physicist, recruit student and faculty participation, and assist with all the formal mentoring sessions. NSHP also promotes informal networking and mentoring between student and faculty participants during common meals and in the hall ways. The number of student attendees has been increasing rapidly in recent years. Attendance at the two scientific sessions which run in parallel has risen to about one hundred fifty participants. A large number of booths manned by universities recruiting graduate students and industries/government laboratories recruiting professional scientists offers students excellent contacts and serves as a valuable source of information as they pursue their career. The Conference allows students to interact with other students of similar background, to meet and interact with scientific leaders in their field, and to be mentored by senior faculty who have been involved in promoting diversity for many years.

Modified by: David J Ernst
